sentences: Juhan on lahtise käega mees, tema ei koonerda.
Tal on lahtine käsi, käed töö peale lahti.
Ants oli äge ja lahtise käega, virutas sulle ilma pikemata täie ära.
context: The word 'kätega' is the instrumental case form of 'käsi' (hand) in Estonian. It means 'with hands' or 'with a hand'. In this context, it's used as part of the phrase 'lahtise käega' which translates to 'with an open hand'. This expression has several meanings: 1) being generous or liberal with giving; 2) skilled at doing something particular (like work); and 3) in some contexts, it can mean hitting lightly. The word shows how Estonian uses case endings to indicate the instrument or means by which something is done - here indicating that the action is performed using hands.
